title: 104_s853
content:
The "Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals Reorganization Act of 1995" amends the number and composition of circuits in the United States Code, increasing the circuits from thirteen to fourteen. It specifically reorganizes the ninth circuit to include Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The "Twelfth Circuit Court of Appeals Reorganization Act" amends the number of circuit judges and the places of circuit court in the United States Code. It increases the circuits from thirteen to fourteen, adding Alaska, Idaho, Montana, Oregon, and Washington to the twelfth circuit. The number of judges for the ninth circuit is reduced to 19, while the twelfth circuit will have 7 judges. SEC. 5. ASSIGNMENT OF CIRCUIT JUDGES.

Each circuit judge in regular active service of the former ninth circuit is reassigned based on their official station before the effective date of the Act. Judges in Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, Guam, or the Northern Mariana Islands are assigned to the new ninth circuit, while judges in Alaska, Idaho, Montana, Oregon, or Washington are assigned to the twelfth circuit.

SEC. 6. ELECTION OF ASSIGNMENT BY SENIOR JUDGES. SEC. 6. ELECTION OF ASSIGNMENT BY SENIOR JUDGES.

Senior judges of the former ninth circuit can choose to be assigned to the new ninth circuit or the twelfth circuit by notifying the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts.

SEC. 7. SENIORITY OF JUDGES.

The seniority of judges assigned under section 5 or those electing assignment under section 6 will be based on their commission date as a judge of the former ninth circuit.

SEC. 8. APPLICATION TO CASES. The provisions in this section apply to cases where an appeal or proceeding was filed with the former ninth circuit before the effective date of this Act. If the matter has been submitted for decision, further proceedings will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. If not submitted, the appeal or proceeding will be transferred to the appropriate court as if the Act was in full force at the time of filing. Further proceedings in respect of the case shall be had in the same manner and with the same effect as if the appeal or other proceeding had been filed in such court. A petition for rehearing or rehearing en banc in a matter decided before the effective date of this Act shall be treated as though this Act had not been enacted. If a rehearing en banc is granted, the matter shall be reheard by a court as though this Act had not been enacted. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS.

For this Act:
(1) "former ninth circuit" refers to the ninth judicial circuit of the United States before the Act.
(2) "new ninth circuit" refers to the ninth judicial circuit established by the Act.
(3) "twelfth circuit" refers to the twelfth judicial circuit established by the Act.

SEC. 10. ADMINISTRATION.

The court of appeals for the ninth circuit before the Act's effective date can take necessary administrative actions. It will cease to exist for administrative purposes on July 1, 1997.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 1995.
